title: 108_hr2630
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commercial Alien Smuggling Elimination Act of 2003" or the "CASE Act of 2003". It introduces a new class of nonimmigrant aliens. The "Commercial Alien Smuggling Elimination Act of 2003" introduces a new class of nonimmigrant aliens who possess critical reliable information about alien smuggling organizations and are willing to share it with the authorities. The "Commercial Alien Smuggling Elimination Act of 2003" allows nonimmigrant aliens with vital information on alien smuggling organizations to cooperate with authorities in criminal investigations and prosecutions. The "Commercial Alien Smuggling Elimination Act of 2003" allows nonimmigrant aliens to cooperate with authorities in criminal investigations and prosecutions. Amendments include limiting the number of nonimmigrant visas under a specific section to 400 per fiscal year and granting officials the authority to protect the identities of certain nonimmigrants and their family members. SEC. 3. Adjustment of status of nonimmigrant to that of person admitted for permanent residence. Section 245(j) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include provisions for nonimmigrants admitted under specific sections who provide information contributing to alien smuggling investigations or prosecutions. The Secretary of Homeland Security may adjust the status of aliens involved in alien smuggling investigations or prosecutions to lawful permanent residence, as well as nonimmigrants admitted under specific sections, based on recommendations from the Secretary of State or Attorney General. The Secretary of Homeland Security, Secretary of State, or Attorney General can adjust the status of individuals involved in alien smuggling investigations to lawful permanent residence. If necessary, these officials can take lawful action to protect the identity of those whose status is adjusted. SEC. 4. BRINGING IN AND HARBORING CERTAIN ALIENS. Criminal penalties under the Immigration and Nationality Act are increased by up to 10 years for individuals who bring aliens into the US in violation of the law, under certain conditions. Additionally, a rewards program is established within the Department. The Nationality Act is amended to establish a rewards program within the Department of Homeland Security to combat commercial alien smuggling involving groups of 10 or more individuals in dangerous conditions. The program will be administered by the Secretary of Homeland Security in consultation with the Attorney General and the Secretary of State. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Attorney General and the Secretary of State, may pay a reward to individuals providing information leading to the arrest or conviction of those involved in commercial alien smuggling endangering lives or posing health risks in the US. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Attorney General and the Secretary of State, may pay a reward to individuals providing information leading to the arrest or conviction of those involved in commercial alien smuggling endangering lives or posing health risks in the US. This includes actions such as arresting or convicting individuals committing or aiding in such acts, preventing or resolving such acts, and identifying key leaders in alien smuggling operations. The subsection authorizes appropriations for combating commercial alien smuggling operations involving the transportation of groups of 10 or more aliens in a manner that endangers lives or poses health risks. Additionally, officers or employees providing information on such activities are ineligible for rewards under this subsection. The subsection authorizes appropriations for combating commercial alien smuggling operations involving the transportation of groups of 10 or more aliens. Individuals providing information described in paragraph (4) are not eligible for rewards under this subsection. Protection measures can be taken to safeguard the identity of informants and their family members. The maximum reward amount is $100,000, unless authorized by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The subsection allows rewards exceeding $100,000 if approved by the Secretary of Homeland Security to combat alien smuggling operations endangering lives or posing health risks. Rewards over $50,000 require personal approval by the Secretary. The Secretary of Homeland Security must personally approve rewards exceeding $50,000 under this subsection. Additionally, an outreach program will be developed to educate the public about penalties for bringing in and harboring aliens in violation of the law. The Secretary of Homeland Security must approve rewards exceeding $50,000. An outreach program will educate the public about penalties for harboring aliens and incentives for assisting in smuggling investigations.
